trans-unit.source: Two-Class Decision Forest
trans-unit.target: Two-Class Decision Forest

trans-unit.source: Creates a two-class classification model using the decision forest algorithm
trans-unit.target: Creates a two-class classification model using the decision forest algorithm

trans-unit.source: Category: <legacyLink xlink:href="0D90DCAB-08E1-4A66-9EA1-B571C22AE74D" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Machine Learning / Initialize Model / Classification</legacyLink>
trans-unit.target: Category: <legacyLink xlink:href="0D90DCAB-08E1-4A66-9EA1-B571C22AE74D" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Machine Learning / Initialize Model / Classification</legacyLink>

trans-unit.source: Module Overview
trans-unit.target: Module Overview

trans-unit.source: You can use the <ui>Two-Class Decision Forest</ui> module to create a machine learning model based on the random decision forests algorithm.
trans-unit.target: You can use the <ui>Two-Class Decision Forest</ui> module to create a machine learning model based on the random decision forests algorithm.

trans-unit.source: Decision forests are fast, supervised ensemble models.
trans-unit.target: Decision forests are fast, supervised ensemble models.

trans-unit.source: This module can be used to predict a target that has two values.
trans-unit.target: This module can be used to predict a target that has two values.

trans-unit.source: Understanding Decision Forests
trans-unit.target: Understanding Decision Forests

trans-unit.source: Decision forests are an ensemble learning method for classification.
trans-unit.target: Decision forests are an ensemble learning method for classification.

trans-unit.source: They work by building multiple decision trees and then voting on the most popular output class.
trans-unit.target: They work by building multiple decision trees and then voting on the most popular output class.

trans-unit.source: Voting is a form of aggregation, in which each tree in a classification decision forest outputs a non-normalized frequency histogram of labels.
trans-unit.target: Voting is a form of aggregation, in which each tree in a classification decision forest outputs a non-normalized frequency histogram of labels.

trans-unit.source: The aggregation process sums these histograms and normalizes the result to get the “probabilities” for each label.
trans-unit.target: The aggregation process sums these histograms and normalizes the result to get the “probabilities” for each label.

trans-unit.source: In this manner, naïvely, trees that think they have a better idea of what the features mean will receive greater weight than trees that aren’t sure.
trans-unit.target: In this manner, naïvely, trees that think they have a better idea of what the features mean will receive greater weight than trees that aren’t sure.

trans-unit.source: Decision trees are non-parametric models, and they support data with varied distributions.
trans-unit.target: Decision trees are non-parametric models, and they support data with varied distributions.

trans-unit.source: In each tree, a sequence of simple tests is run for each class, increasing the levels of a tree structure until a leaf node (decision) is reached.
trans-unit.target: In each tree, a sequence of simple tests is run for each class, increasing the levels of a tree structure until a leaf node (decision) is reached.

trans-unit.source: Decision trees have many advantages:
trans-unit.target: Decision trees have many advantages:

trans-unit.source: They can represent non-linear decision boundaries.
trans-unit.target: They can represent non-linear decision boundaries.

trans-unit.source: They are efficient in computation and memory usage during training and prediction.
trans-unit.target: They are efficient in computation and memory usage during training and prediction.

trans-unit.source: They perform integrated feature selection and classification.
trans-unit.target: They perform integrated feature selection and classification.

trans-unit.source: They are resilient in the presence of noisy features.
trans-unit.target: They are resilient in the presence of noisy features.

trans-unit.source: This decision forest classifier consists of an ensemble of decision trees.
trans-unit.target: This decision forest classifier consists of an ensemble of decision trees.

trans-unit.source: Generally, ensemble models provide better coverage and accuracy than single decision trees.
trans-unit.target: Generally, ensemble models provide better coverage and accuracy than single decision trees.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <externalLink><linkText>Decision Forests</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=403677</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <externalLink><linkText>Decision Forests</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=403677</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: This blog article by Microsoft Research also provides useful information about ensemble methods that use decision trees.
trans-unit.target: This blog article by Microsoft Research also provides useful information about ensemble methods that use decision trees.

trans-unit.source: <externalLink><linkText>From Stumps to Trees to Forests</linkText><linkUri>http://blogs.technet.com/b/machinelearning/archive/2014/09/10/from-stumps-to-trees-to-forests.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: <externalLink><linkText>From Stumps to Trees to Forests</linkText><linkUri>http://blogs.technet.com/b/machinelearning/archive/2014/09/10/from-stumps-to-trees-to-forests.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: How to Configure Two-Class Decision Forest
trans-unit.target: How to Configure Two-Class Decision Forest

trans-unit.source: Drag the <ui>Two-Class Decision Forest</ui> module into your experiment.
trans-unit.target: Drag the <ui>Two-Class Decision Forest</ui> module into your experiment.

trans-unit.source: Set model <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_Options" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">options</legacyLink>.
trans-unit.target: Set model <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_Options" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">options</legacyLink>.

trans-unit.source: Connect an instance of <link xlink:href="5cc7053e-aa30-450d-96c0-dae4be720977" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Train Model</link> to train the model using a tagged dataset.
trans-unit.target: Connect an instance of <link xlink:href="5cc7053e-aa30-450d-96c0-dae4be720977" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Train Model</link> to train the model using a tagged dataset.

trans-unit.source: <newTerm>Tagged</newTerm> means that the dataset contains a label column that contains two or more predicted outcomes.
trans-unit.target: <newTerm>Tagged</newTerm> means that the dataset contains a label column that contains two or more predicted outcomes.

trans-unit.source: The trained model can then be used to make predictions.
trans-unit.target: The trained model can then be used to make predictions.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, the untrained model can be passed to <link xlink:href="75fb875d-6b86-4d46-8bcc-74261ade5826" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Cross Validate Model</link> for cross-validation against a labeled data set.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, the untrained model can be passed to <link xlink:href="75fb875d-6b86-4d46-8bcc-74261ade5826" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Cross Validate Model</link> for cross-validation against a labeled data set.

trans-unit.source: Options
trans-unit.target: Options

trans-unit.source: This module supports extensive customization of the decision forest algorithm using these parameters:
trans-unit.target: This module supports extensive customization of the decision forest algorithm using these parameters:

trans-unit.source: Resampling method
trans-unit.target: Resampling method

trans-unit.source: Specify which method should be used to combine the results of individual trees.
trans-unit.target: Specify which method should be used to combine the results of individual trees.

trans-unit.source: You can choose from <ui>Bagging</ui> or <ui>Replicate</ui>.
trans-unit.target: You can choose from <ui>Bagging</ui> or <ui>Replicate</ui>.

trans-unit.source: <legacyItalic><ui>Bagging</ui></legacyItalic>.
trans-unit.target: <legacyItalic><ui>Bagging</ui></legacyItalic>.

trans-unit.source: Bagging is also called <newTerm>bootstrap aggregating</newTerm>.
trans-unit.target: Bagging is also called <newTerm>bootstrap aggregating</newTerm>.

trans-unit.source: In this method, each tree is grown on a new sample, created by randomly sampling the original dataset with replacement until you have a dataset the size of the original.
trans-unit.target: In this method, each tree is grown on a new sample, created by randomly sampling the original dataset with replacement until you have a dataset the size of the original.

trans-unit.source: The outputs of the models are combined by <newTerm>voting</newTerm>, which is a form of aggregation.
trans-unit.target: The outputs of the models are combined by <newTerm>voting</newTerm>, which is a form of aggregation.

trans-unit.source: Each tree in a classification decision forest outputs an un-normalised frequency histogram of labels.
trans-unit.target: Each tree in a classification decision forest outputs an un-normalised frequency histogram of labels.

trans-unit.source: The aggregation is to sum these histograms and normalise to get the “probabilities” for each label.
trans-unit.target: The aggregation is to sum these histograms and normalise to get the “probabilities” for each label.

trans-unit.source: In this manner, naïvely, trees that think they have a better idea of what the features mean will receive greater weight than trees that aren’t sure.
trans-unit.target: In this manner, naïvely, trees that think they have a better idea of what the features mean will receive greater weight than trees that aren’t sure.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the Wikipedia entry for Bootstrap aggregating.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the Wikipedia entry for Bootstrap aggregating.

trans-unit.source: <legacyItalic><ui>Replicate</ui></legacyItalic>.
trans-unit.target: <legacyItalic><ui>Replicate</ui></legacyItalic>.

trans-unit.source: In replication, each tree is trained on exactly the same input data.
trans-unit.target: In replication, each tree is trained on exactly the same input data.

trans-unit.source: Number of decision trees
trans-unit.target: Number of decision trees

trans-unit.source: Configure the maximum number of decision trees that can be created in the ensemble.
trans-unit.target: Configure the maximum number of decision trees that can be created in the ensemble.

trans-unit.source: By creating more decision trees, you can potentially get better coverage, but training time will increase.
trans-unit.target: By creating more decision trees, you can potentially get better coverage, but training time will increase.

trans-unit.source: Maximum depth of the decision trees
trans-unit.target: Maximum depth of the decision trees

trans-unit.source: Type a number to constrain the maximum depth of any decision tree.
trans-unit.target: Type a number to constrain the maximum depth of any decision tree.

trans-unit.source: Increasing the depth of the tree might increase precision, at the risk of some overfitting and increased training time.
trans-unit.target: Increasing the depth of the tree might increase precision, at the risk of some overfitting and increased training time.

trans-unit.source: Number of random splits per node
trans-unit.target: Number of random splits per node

trans-unit.source: Specify the number of splits to use when building each node of the tree.
trans-unit.target: Specify the number of splits to use when building each node of the tree.

trans-unit.source: Features in each level of the tree (node) are randomly divided.
trans-unit.target: Features in each level of the tree (node) are randomly divided.

trans-unit.source: Minimum number of samples per leaf node
trans-unit.target: Minimum number of samples per leaf node

trans-unit.source: Type a number to specify the minimum number of samples required to create any terminal node (leaf) in a tree.
trans-unit.target: Type a number to specify the minimum number of samples required to create any terminal node (leaf) in a tree.

trans-unit.source: By increasing this value, you increase the threshold for creating new rules.
trans-unit.target: By increasing this value, you increase the threshold for creating new rules.

trans-unit.source: For example, with the default value of 1, even a single case can cause a new rule to be created.
trans-unit.target: For example, with the default value of 1, even a single case can cause a new rule to be created.

trans-unit.source: If you increase the value to 5, the training data would have to contain at least 5 cases that meet the same conditions.
trans-unit.target: If you increase the value to 5, the training data would have to contain at least 5 cases that meet the same conditions.

trans-unit.source: Allow unknown values for categorical features
trans-unit.target: Allow unknown values for categorical features

trans-unit.source: Select this option to create a group for unknown values in the training or validation sets.
trans-unit.target: Select this option to create a group for unknown values in the training or validation sets.

trans-unit.source: If you deselect it, the model can accept only the values that are contained in the training data.
trans-unit.target: If you deselect it, the model can accept only the values that are contained in the training data.

trans-unit.source: In the former case, the model might be less precise for known values, but it can provide better predictions for new (unknown) values.
trans-unit.target: In the former case, the model might be less precise for known values, but it can provide better predictions for new (unknown) values.

trans-unit.source: Recommendations
trans-unit.target: Recommendations

trans-unit.source: If you have limited data or you want to minimize the time spent training the model, try these settings:
trans-unit.target: If you have limited data or you want to minimize the time spent training the model, try these settings:

trans-unit.source: <legacyBold>Limited training set</legacyBold>: If the training set contains a limited number of instances, you can:
trans-unit.target: <legacyBold>Limited training set</legacyBold>: If the training set contains a limited number of instances, you can:

trans-unit.source: Create the decision forest by using a large number of decision trees (for example, more than 20).
trans-unit.target: Create the decision forest by using a large number of decision trees (for example, more than 20).

trans-unit.source: Use the <ui>Bagging</ui> option for resampling.
trans-unit.target: Use the <ui>Bagging</ui> option for resampling.

trans-unit.source: Specify a large number of random splits per node (for example, more than 1,000).
trans-unit.target: Specify a large number of random splits per node (for example, more than 1,000).

trans-unit.source: <legacyBold>Limited training time</legacyBold>: If the training set contains a large number of instances and training time is limited, you can:
trans-unit.target: <legacyBold>Limited training time</legacyBold>: If the training set contains a large number of instances and training time is limited, you can:

trans-unit.source: Create the decision forest by using fewer decision trees (for example, 5-10).
trans-unit.target: Create the decision forest by using fewer decision trees (for example, 5-10).

trans-unit.source: Use the <ui>Replicate</ui> option for resampling.
trans-unit.target: Use the <ui>Replicate</ui> option for resampling.

trans-unit.source: Specify a smaller number of random splits per node (for example, fewer than 100).
trans-unit.target: Specify a smaller number of random splits per node (for example, fewer than 100).

trans-unit.source: Example
trans-unit.target: Example

trans-unit.source: For examples of how decision forests are used in machine learning, see this sample experiment in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink>:
trans-unit.target: For examples of how decision forests are used in machine learning, see this sample experiment in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink>:

trans-unit.source: The <externalLink><linkText>News categorization</linkText><linkUri>https://gallery.azureml.net/Experiment/fcb1bf27ee26443fb19bd07852a620c4</linkUri></externalLink> sample compares a multiclass classifier to a model built using the <ui>Two-Class Decision Forest</ui> algorithm with the <link xlink:href="7191efae-b4b1-4d03-a6f8-7205f87be664" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">One vs. All Classifier</link>.
trans-unit.target: The <externalLink><linkText>News categorization</linkText><linkUri>https://gallery.azureml.net/Experiment/fcb1bf27ee26443fb19bd07852a620c4</linkUri></externalLink> sample compares a multiclass classifier to a model built using the <ui>Two-Class Decision Forest</ui> algorithm with the <link xlink:href="7191efae-b4b1-4d03-a6f8-7205f87be664" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">One vs. All Classifier</link>.

trans-unit.source: The <externalLink><linkText>Predictive maintenance</linkText><linkUri>https://gallery.azureml.net/Experiment/6835de908e6b479e92f2e221e7d18195</linkUri></externalLink> sample is an extended walkthrough that uses the <ui>Two-Class Decision Forest</ui> algorithm to predict if an asset will fail within certain time frame.
trans-unit.target: The <externalLink><linkText>Predictive maintenance</linkText><linkUri>https://gallery.azureml.net/Experiment/6835de908e6b479e92f2e221e7d18195</linkUri></externalLink> sample is an extended walkthrough that uses the <ui>Two-Class Decision Forest</ui> algorithm to predict if an asset will fail within certain time frame.
